thread.title: Valencia football scores 21 unanswered in win over Saugus
thread.title_full: Valencia football scores 21 unanswered in win over Saugus

author: Lorrie Reyes
title: Valencia football scores 21 unanswered in win over Saugus
text:
Valencia football scores 21 unanswered in win over Saugus Vikings running back Berkley scores twice in win Posted: October 16, 2015 10:26   16, 2015 10:26 p.m. Valencia’s Effie Davalos (25) rushes for a gain against Saugus at COC Friday. Photo by Jayne Kamin-Oncea/For The Signal Saugus' Kerner Mark, center, lifts David Aubrey in the air after Aubrey ran for a touchdown in the first quarter at College of the Canyons on Friday. Photo by Jayne Kamin-Oncea/For The Signal 
Down by seven in the first half, Valencia gave the ball to running back Jahmar Berkley three times in a row. 
On the first, he grabbed 2 yards on fourth-and-1 at the Saugus 25. 
Then he rattled off a 10-yard run. 
And on his third touch, Berkley rolled out to the right side to tie the score. 
That was a part of 21 unanswered points that lifted the Vikings to a 21-7 win over the Centurions at College of the Canyons on Friday night. 
Berkley ran for 148 yards on 11 carries and scored two of Valencia’s three touchdowns on the night. 
His second score sealed the win in the fourth quarter for the Vikings (4-3 overall, 2-0 in Foothill) — a 7-yard run after a quick, backward pitch from quarterback Cole Parkinson. 
Parkinson went 6-for-14 for 34 yards with an interception and two fumbles on the night. 
But the Vikings were the beneficiaries of good field position for most of the evening, and Jermaine Brown picked off Saugus quarterback Louis Eusebi in the second quarter. 
Valencia took advantage of the pick as Effie Davalos ran in a score up the right side from 7-yards out. 
Davalos ran for 53 yards on nine carries and a TD. 
Eusebi finished the night 12-for-25 and 117 yards in the air. He wasn’t as effective this week on the ground, rushing for 67 yards on 19 attempts. 
He ran for 153 yards against West Ranch last week. 
The Cents’ lone touchdown drive was methodical. 
They went 80 yards in 13 plays (10 rushing) while taking five minutes off the clock. Running back David Aubrey capped the drive off with a 2-yard touchdown run. But it was highlighted by a Eusebi 18-yard run on which he leaped over a defender on third-and-2. 
Neither Valencia and Saugus could get anything going offensively in the second half, though. 
The first first down for either team didn’t come until the fourth quarter when Saugus began running its no-huddle offense, something it had abandoned in the beginning of the game. 
Saugus head coach Jason Bornn was not on the sideline. It was unclear why the 13-year head coach was not at the helm. 
Up next for Saugus (3-4, 1-1) is a trip to Canyon High. Valencia plays West Ranch.
